openai_summarised_points: • The economy of South Africa is the largest economy in Africa, characterized as a mixed economy, emerging market, and upper-middle-income economy, and is one of only eight such countries on the continent.
• South Africa's economy is the most industrialised, technologically advanced, and diversified in Africa.
• Following the end of over twelve years of international sanctions in 1996, South Africa’s nominal gross domestic product (GDP) nearly tripled, reaching a peak of US$416 billion in 2011.

• During the same period (1996 to 2011), foreign exchange reserves increased from US$3 billion to nearly US$50 billion, contributing to the creation of a diversified economy with a growing and sizable middle class within three decades of ending apartheid.
• The natural resource extraction industry remains one of the largest sectors in South Africa, contributing US$13.5 billion annually to the GDP.
• Since the end of apartheid, the South African economy has diversified significantly, particularly towards the services sector.
• In 2019, the financial industry contributed US$41.4 billion to South Africa’s GDP.
• By 2021, South Africa-based financial institutions managed assets totaling more than US$1.41 trillion.
• The Johannesburg Stock Exchange had a total market capitalization of US$1.28 trillion as of October 2021.
• State-owned enterprises (SOEs) play a significant role in South Africa’s economy, with the government owning shares in approximately 700 SOEs across a wide range of important industries.

• In 2016, business executives identified the top five challenges to doing business in South Africa as inefficient government bureaucracy, restrictive labour regulations, a shortage of skilled workers in some high-tech industries, political instability, and corruption.
• The banking sector in South Africa was rated as a strongly positive feature of the economy.
• South Africa is a member of the G20 and is the only African country with permanent membership in this group.
• South Africa is a popular destination for offshoring, with many international companies relocating operations or services to the country.
• A 2025 report by Robert Walters plc found that 60% of business leaders ranked South Africa as the most attractive country for offshoring, surpassing other popular regions by a large margin.

• Key reasons for offshoring to South Africa include access to skilled talent, retained earnings, strong English proficiency, time zone alignment with major markets, and a growing reputation for business and technology services.
• The "Tech and IT" industry is the main sector showing considerable growth in offshoring activities to South Africa, accounting for 53% of new roles.
• Other significant offshoring sectors include "customer service and support," "finance and accounting," and "human resources and recruitment."
• South Africa’s combination of skilled talent, strong infrastructure, and alignment with international business practices makes it a strategic location for building global business capabilities.
• The formal economy of South Africa originated in 1652 with the arrival of Dutch settlers sent by the Dutch East India Company to establish a provisioning station for passing ships.

• The colony expanded with the arrival of Huguenots and German colonists, some of whom were freed to pursue commercial farming, leading to agriculture becoming the dominant sector in the early economy.

• At the end of the 18th century, the British annexed the colony, which prompted the Great Trek, a migration of Afrikaner farmers deeper into the mainland, and the establishment of the independent Afrikaner Republics of the Transvaal and the Orange Free State.

• In 1870, diamonds were discovered in Kimberley, and in 1886, some of the world’s largest gold deposits were found in the Witwatersrand region of Transvaal, rapidly transforming South Africa’s economy into one dominated by mineral resources.
• Following the Second Boer War, the British annexed the Transvaal and Orange Free State, employing scorched earth tactics against Boer non-combatants during the conflict.
• The period also saw the beginning of industrialization in South Africa, including the formation of the first South African trade unions.

• Racial segregation laws were progressively introduced, culminating in 1948 when the National Party won the national elections and implemented Apartheid, a strict race-based policy aimed at protecting the white minority from the growing black population.
• Apartheid policies faced widespread international condemnation and led to severe economic sanctions against South Africa during the 1980s.

• South Africa held its first non-racial elections in 1994, resulting in the African National Congress (ANC) government taking office with the challenge of rebuilding an economy damaged by sanctions and integrating previously disadvantaged populations.

• The post-apartheid government avoided economic populism, successfully reducing inflation, stabilizing public finances, and attracting some foreign investment, although economic growth remained below expectations.

• In 2000, President Thabo Mbeki committed to boosting economic growth and foreign investment by relaxing restrictive labor laws, accelerating privatization, increasing government spending, and sharply cutting interest rates from 1998 levels, despite strong opposition from organized labor.
• From 2004 onwards, South Africa experienced significant economic growth, with increases in both employment and capital formation.

• In April 2009, amid concerns about a global recession, Reserve Bank Governor Tito Mboweni predicted further economic decline, labeling the situation a recession, while Finance Minister Trevor Manuel anticipated a quarter of economic growth.
• Nobel laureate economist Joseph Stiglitz advised in 2009 that inflation targeting should be deprioritized during the 2008 financial crisis to better support South Africa’s economy.

• Unlike many emerging markets, South Africa struggled through the late-2000s recession, with recovery primarily driven by private and public consumption growth, while export volumes and private investment remained subdued.

• The long-term potential growth rate under the prevailing policy environment was estimated at 3.5%, with per capita GDP growth averaging 1.6% annually from 1994 to 2009 and 2.2% during the 2000–09 decade, compared to a global average of 3.1% over the same periods.

• High unemployment rates exceeding 25% and significant economic inequality are regarded by the government and the majority of South Africans as the most critical economic challenges facing the country.
• These socioeconomic issues, along with related problems such as crime, have negatively impacted investment and economic growth, creating a feedback loop that further exacerbates unemployment.
• Crime is identified as a major or very severe constraint on investment by 30% of South African enterprises, ranking it among the top four most frequently cited investment constraints.

• In April 2017, political tensions escalated following President Jacob Zuma’s dismissal of nine cabinet members, including Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan, who was viewed as pivotal to restoring economic confidence.

• The cabinet reshuffle led to S&P Global downgrading South Africa’s credit rating to junk status on 3 April 2017, followed by Fitch Ratings lowering the rating to sub-investment grade BBB− on 7 April 2017.
• Following the cabinet changes and credit rating downgrades, the South African rand depreciated by more than 11% within the week.
• From 1980 to 2022, South Africa's GDP in billion US$ PPP increased from 148.6 in 1980 to 949.8 in 2022, reflecting significant economic growth over the period.
• Real GDP per capita in US$ PPP rose from 5,110 in 1980 to 15,556 in 2022, indicating a nearly threefold increase in average economic output per person.
• Nominal GDP in billion US$ fluctuated, starting at 89.4 in 1980, peaking at 458.7 in 2011, and reaching 405.7 in 2022, showing variations influenced by exchange rates and inflation.
• Nominal GDP per capita in US$ increased from 3,075 in 1980 to 6,694 in 2022, with a peak of 8,799 in 2011, reflecting changes in currency value and economic conditions.

• Real GDP growth rates varied widely, with positive growth in most years, including peaks of 6.6% in 1980 and 5.6% in 2006, but also experienced negative growth during recessions such as −6.3% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

• Inflation rates fluctuated significantly, with several years under 5% (highlighted in green in the original table), such as 1.4% in 2004 and 0.3% in 2019, while reaching highs of 18.1% in 1986 and 15.3% in 1981.
• Unemployment rates increased from 9.2% in 1980 to a peak of 34.6% in 2022, demonstrating a persistent and growing challenge in the South African labor market.

• Government debt as a percentage of GDP was not available for the early 1980s but rose from 37.9% in 2000 to a peak of 69.0% in 2020 and 2021, before slightly decreasing to 68.0% in 2022, indicating increasing fiscal pressures.
• The nominal GDP in US$ at market prices estimated by the International Monetary Fund showed fluctuations from 80.547 billion US$ in 1980 to 337.880 billion US$ in 2020.
• The South African Rand to US dollar exchange rate depreciated substantially from 0.8267 Rand per US dollar in 1980 to 14.65 Rand in 2020, reflecting currency devaluation over four decades.
• Unemployment rates reported by the IMF increased from 9.2% in 1980 to 29.2% in 2020, corroborating the trend of rising joblessness in South Africa.

• Per capita income in US$ according to IMF data rose from 2,764 in 1980, peaked at 7,274 in 2010, and declined to 5,638 in 2020, indicating fluctuations in individual income levels amid economic volatility.

• Key economic indicators demonstrate that South Africa experienced periods of economic expansion, inflation control, and currency depreciation, alongside persistent challenges such as high unemployment and increasing government debt from 1980 through 2022.

• South Africa possesses a comparative advantage in the production of agricultural, mining, and manufacturing products related to these sectors, reflecting its resource endowments and industrial capabilities.

• Historically, South Africa's economy transitioned from being primarily based on the primary (agriculture, mining) and secondary (manufacturing) sectors in the mid-twentieth century to a predominantly tertiary sector-driven economy in the present day.

• The tertiary sector currently accounts for approximately 65% of South Africa's Gross Domestic Product (GDP), equating to an estimated $230 billion in nominal GDP terms, highlighting the service-oriented nature of the modern economy.

• The South African economy is reasonably diversified, comprising several key sectors including mining, agriculture and fisheries, vehicle manufacturing and assembly, food processing, clothing and textiles, telecommunications, energy, financial and business services, real estate, tourism, manufacturing, information technology (IT), transportation, and wholesale and retail trade.

• According to seasonally adjusted and annualised quarterly value added data for the first quarter of 2013 (Q1 2013) measured in billion South African Rand (R) at 2004 prices, the value added by each industry sector was as follows:
• Agriculture, forestry, and fishing contributed R43.382 billion.
• Mining and quarrying contributed R97.096 billion.
• Manufacturing, including the space industry, contributed R296.586 billion.
• Electricity, gas, and water contributed R33.951 billion.
• Construction contributed R59.943 billion.
• Wholesale and retail trade, hotels, and restaurants contributed R246.584 billion.
• Transport, storage, and communication contributed R178.591 billion.
• Finance, real estate, and business services contributed the highest value added at R422.850 billion.
• General government services contributed R271.209 billion.
• Personal services contributed R107.690 billion.
• Taxes less subsidies on products accounted for R215.668 billion.
• The total GDP at market prices for South Africa in Q1 2013 was R1,973.552 billion, reflecting the aggregate economic output across all sectors during that period.

• In 2019, South Africa was the world's largest producer of platinum, chromium, and manganese, the 2nd largest producer of titanium, the 3rd largest producer of vanadium, the 6th largest producer of iron ore, the 11th largest producer of gold and cobalt, the 12th largest producer of uranium in 2018, and the 15th largest producer of phosphate globally.

• Mining has historically been the principal driver of South Africa's economic development, beginning with the discovery of a diamond by Erasmus Jacobs on the Orange River in 1867, followed by the exploitation of the Kimberley pipes shortly thereafter.

• Early gold rushes occurred at Pilgrim's Rest and Barberton, culminating in the major discovery of the Main Reef/Main Reef Leader on Gerhardus Oosthuizen's farm Langlaagte, Portion C, in 1886, which triggered the Witwatersrand Gold Rush and rapid development of the largest goldfield in South Africa.

• South Africa remains one of the world's leading mining and mineral-processing nations, although mining's contribution to the national GDP declined from 21% in 1970 to 6% in 2011, it still accounts for nearly 60% of the country's exports and contributes up to 9% of value added in the economy.

• In 2008, South Africa's estimated share of global production included 77% of platinum, 55% of kyanite and related materials, 45% of chromium, 39% of palladium and vermiculite each, 38% of vanadium, 30% of zirconium, 21% of manganese, 20% of rutile, 19% of ilmenite, 11% of gold, 6% of fluorspar, 2% each of aluminium, antimony, iron ore, and nickel, and 1% of phosphate rock.
• The country also accounted for nearly 5% of the world's polished diamond production by value in 2008.

• South Africa holds significant world reserves, including 89% of platinum group metals, 46% of hafnium, 27% of zirconium, 23% of vanadium, 19% of manganese, 18% each of rutile and fluorspar, 13% of gold, 10% of phosphate rock, 9% of ilmenite, and 5% of nickel.
• Additionally, South Africa is the world's third largest exporter of coal.

• The mining sector in South Africa comprises a combination of privately owned and state-controlled mines, with the African Exploration Mining and Finance Corporation representing a notable state-controlled entity.

• In 2018, South Africa produced 19.3 million tonnes of sugarcane, ranking as the 14th largest producer globally, 12.5 million tonnes of maize (12th largest producer worldwide), 1.9 million tons of grapes (11th largest producer), 1.7 million tons of oranges (11th largest producer), and 397 thousand tons of pears (7th largest producer in the world).

• Additional 2018 agricultural production figures include 2.4 million tons of potatoes, 1.8 million tons of wheat, 1.5 million tons of soy, 862 thousand tons of sunflower seed, 829 thousand tons of apples, 726 thousand tons of onions, 537 thousand tons of tomatoes, 474 thousand tons of lemons, 445 thousand tons of grapefruit, 444 thousand tons of bananas, and 421 thousand tons of barley.
• South Africa also produces smaller quantities of various other agricultural products such as avocado, pineapple, peach, tangerine, pumpkin, cabbage, carrot, rapeseed, and sorghum.

• The agricultural industry accounts for approximately 5% of formal employment in South Africa, which is relatively low compared to other African countries, and contributes around 2.8% to the national GDP.
• Due to the arid nature of much of South African land, only 13.5% of the land area is suitable for crop production, with merely 3% classified as high potential agricultural land.

• The agricultural sector faces significant challenges including increased foreign competition and crime, with ongoing debates about the adequacy of government efforts to address farm attacks relative to other violent crimes.

• Maize production, which constitutes 36% of the gross value of South Africa’s field crops, has been negatively impacted by climate change, with estimated losses ranging from tens to hundreds of millions of Rands, considering scenarios both with and without the carbon dioxide fertilization effect.

• According to FAOSTAT data, South Africa ranks among the world’s largest producers in several categories: 4th in chicory roots and grapefruit, 5th in cereals, 7th in green maize and maize, 9th in castor oil seed and pears, and 10th in sisal and fibre crops.

• In the first quarter of 2010, South Africa’s agricultural sector earned export revenues totaling R10.1 billion while spending R8.4 billion on imported agricultural products, resulting in a positive trade balance of R1.7 billion.

• The most significant agricultural exports in early 2010 included edible fruit and nuts, beverages, preserved food, tobacco, cereals, wool not carded or combed, miscellaneous food items, sugar, meat, milling products, malt, and starch, collectively accounting for over 80% of agricultural export revenue.

• Major agricultural imports during the same period, constituting over 60% of import value, included cereals, meat, soya-bean oil cake, beverages, soya-bean oil and its fractions, tobacco, palm oil and its fractions, miscellaneous food, spices, coffee, tea, and preserved food.
• The dairy industry in South Africa comprises approximately 4,300 milk producers, providing employment for around 60,000 farm workers and supporting the livelihoods of an additional 40,000 people.
• Within the agro-processing sector, the food sub-sector is the largest employer, contributing 1.4% to total employment nationally and 11.5% within the manufacturing sector.
• In 2006, the agro-processing sector accounted for 24.7% of South Africa’s total manufacturing output.
• Despite the overall economy gaining 975,941 jobs between 1995 and 2006, the agro-processing sector experienced a net loss of 45,977 jobs during this period.

• Competitive pressures from international markets, particularly China and India, contributed to declines in exports within the food, textiles, and paper sub-sectors, as these sectors faced competition from lower-cost producers abroad.

• Conversely, increased exports from the beverages, tobacco, wood, and leather sub-sectors during this time are attributed to the presence of large, dominant South African firms that have maintained competitiveness in global markets.
• The manufacturing industry in South Africa contributes 13.3% of jobs and 15% of the country's GDP, indicating a relatively small role in the overall economy.

• Certain manufacturing sectors are experiencing growth, notably the Space industry, which is expected to increase employment in both space-related jobs and supporting technology and manufacturing sectors.

• Labour costs in South Africa are low compared to developed countries but remain higher than in most other emerging markets, while the costs of transport, communications, and general living are significantly higher.
• The South African automotive industry represents approximately 10% of the country's manufacturing exports, contributes 7.5% to GDP, and employs around 36,000 people.
• In 2007, South Africa produced 535,000 vehicles out of a global total of 73 million units, with vehicle exports reaching about 170,000 units that year.
• The main export destinations for South African vehicles in 2007 were Japan (approximately 29% of total export value), Australia (20%), the United Kingdom (12%), and the United States (11%).
• In 2006, South Africa exported automotive components valued at ZAR 30.3 billion.
• Major automobile manufacturers with production plants in South Africa include BMW, Ford, Volkswagen, Daimler-Chrysler, General Motors, Nissan, and Toyota.
• Prominent automotive component manufacturers based in South Africa include Arvin Exhaust, Bloxwitch, Corning, and Senior Flexonics.
• The country hosts about 200 automotive component manufacturers operating exclusively in the sector, with an additional 150 suppliers serving the industry on a non-exclusive basis.
• The automotive manufacturing industry is geographically concentrated in the Eastern Cape and Gauteng provinces.

• South African automotive producers benefit from relatively low production costs and preferential access to new markets through trade agreements with the European Union and the Southern African Development Community (SADC).

• The manufacturing sector experienced a sharp decline of 10.4% in 2009 but rebounded with a 5% growth in 2010, driven mainly by the automotive, basic chemicals, iron and steel, and food and beverages industries.
• Despite the 2010 recovery, the manufacturing sector's performance remains constrained by weak demand in South Africa’s primary export markets located in the developed world.
• The "Tourism" section under the "Economy of South Africa" chapter is currently empty as of April 2023.
• There are no key details, facts, statistics, dates, names, or concepts provided in this section at this time.
• Readers and contributors are encouraged to add information to this section to enhance the content related to tourism in South Africa.

• The domestic telecommunications infrastructure in South Africa delivers modern and efficient services to both urban and rural areas, encompassing cellular and internet services ranging from 5G technology to Gigabit Broadband speeds.

• In 1997, Telkom, the South African telecommunications parastatal, underwent partial privatisation and entered into a strategic equity partnership with a consortium led by SBC (AT&T), in exchange for a five-year monopoly to provide certain telecommunications services.
• As part of its obligations following privatisation, Telkom committed to facilitating network modernization and expanding telecommunications infrastructure into previously unserved areas.

• A Second Network Operator, Neotel, was planned to be licensed in 2002 to compete with Telkom across its full spectrum of telecommunications services; however, official licensing only commenced in late 2005.

• South Africa’s mobile telecommunications market is served by five major mobile-phone companies, collectively providing services to over 50 million subscribers, positioning the country as having the fourth most advanced mobile telecommunications network globally.
• The five principal cellular providers in South Africa are Vodacom, MTN, Cell C (a subsidiary of Vodacom), Telkom Mobile (operating under the brand 8.ta), and Rain.
• Neotel, which was owned by Liquid Telecoms, no longer offers mobile services.

• The South African space industry is experiencing growth, with an increasing number of domestic companies providing space-related services; with appropriate government legislation and support, this sector is expected to expand further within the country.
• Over the last few decades, South Africa, particularly the Cape Town region, has established itself as a successful destination for call centres and business process outsourcing (BPO).
• Cape Town benefits from a highly talented and productive labour pool, which contributes to its attractiveness for BPO operations.
• The region shares a cultural affinity with Britain, enhancing communication and operational compatibility with British and other English-speaking companies.
• Several large overseas firms, including Lufthansa, Amazon.com, ASDA, The Carphone Warehouse, and Delta Airlines, have established inbound call centres in Cape Town.
• These companies utilize Cape Town's combination of low labour costs and skilled labour force to optimize their customer service and business process operations.
• South Africa is a popular tourist destination, receiving approximately 860,000 arrivals per month as of March 2008, with around 210,000 of these arrivals coming from outside the African continent.
• In 2012, South Africa recorded a total of 9.2 million international arrivals, indicating significant growth in its tourism sector.
• In August 2017 alone, South Africa welcomed 3.5 million travellers, reflecting the country’s sustained appeal to both domestic and international tourists.
• According to the World Travel & Tourism Council, travel and tourism directly contributed ZAR102 billion to South Africa’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in 2012.
• The tourism sector supports 10.3% of jobs in South Africa, highlighting its importance as a major employment generator within the country.
• Key attractions driving tourism in South Africa include its diverse and picturesque landscapes, numerous game reserves, and the highly regarded local wine industry.

• South Africa’s borders were reopened on 1 October 2020 after closures related to the COVID-19 pandemic, with exceptions imposed on tourists arriving from certain European countries and the United States due to high levels of COVID-19 activity in those regions.
• South Africa possesses a sophisticated financial structure, highlighted by the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) Limited, which is the largest stock exchange on the African continent.
• As of August 2020, the JSE Limited ranked 17th globally in terms of total market capitalisation, valued at $1,005 trillion.
• The South African banking industry is regulated by the South African Reserve Bank (SARB), the country’s central bank.
• The banking sector is predominantly controlled by four major local banks: Nedbank, ABSA, Standard Bank, and FirstRand.
• These banks offer a comprehensive range of services, including both retail banking and investment banking.
• Since the mid-1990s, the South African banking sector has become highly competitive due to the re-entry of many experienced foreign banks that had exited the market in the late 1980s.
• When banks in South Africa experience liquidity shortages, they are required to borrow funds from the South African Reserve Bank at a fluctuating repo rate.
• The repo rate mechanism enables the SARB to effectively monitor and manage liquidity positions within the banking sector.
• South Africa's informal sector contributes 8% to the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP), highlighting its significant role in the national economy.
• The informal sector supports 27% of all working individuals in South Africa, indicating its importance as a source of employment for over a quarter of the workforce.

• The South African Local Economic Development Network estimates the informal economy's value at 28% of South Africa's GDP, suggesting a potentially larger economic impact than official figures indicate.

• Due to the substantial contribution of the informal sector to both GDP and employment, there is ongoing interest in developing inclusive urban planning strategies aimed at supporting the working poor engaged in informal economic activities.

• Between 1992 and 2011, South African exports and imports showed distinct trends, with exports represented in dark blue and imports in light blue on the top graph, while the bottom graph illustrated South Africa's balance of trade over the same period.
• South Africa's principal international trading partners, aside from other African countries, include Germany, the United States, China, Japan, the United Kingdom, Bangladesh, and Spain.
• The chief exports of South Africa consist of corn, diamonds, fruits, gold, metals and minerals, sugar, and wool.
• More than one-third of the value of South Africa's imports is comprised of machinery and transportation equipment.
• Other significant imports into South Africa include chemicals, manufactured goods, and petroleum.

• Following a bilateral agreement in November 1993, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) was authorized to assist US investors in South Africa by providing services such as political risk insurance, loans, and loan guarantees.

• In July 1996, the United States and South Africa signed an investment fund protocol establishing a $120 million OPIC fund aimed at making equity investments in South Africa and the broader Southern African region.
• OPIC is also in the process of establishing the Sub-Saharan Africa Infrastructure Fund, capitalized at $350 million, to invest in infrastructure projects across the region.
• The U.S. Trade and Development Agency has been actively involved in South Africa by funding feasibility studies and identifying investment opportunities for U.S. businesses.
• Despite positive economic developments since 1994, South Africa has faced challenges in attracting significant foreign direct investment (FDI).
• A notable shift occurred in 2005 when South Africa received its largest single FDI to date, with Barclays acquiring a majority share in the local bank Absa Group Limited.
• In 2006, deals were made between the British-based Vodafone and South Africa's Vodacom, indicating increased foreign investment activity.
• In 2010, two major multibillion-dollar acquisition attempts failed: HSBC's bid to acquire Nedbank and Walmart's bid to acquire Massmart Holdings.
• Walmart eventually succeeded in acquiring Massmart Holdings in 2011, marking a significant foreign investment milestone.
• South Africa has experienced intense debates regarding the potential nationalisation of its mineral resources, reflecting deep divisions over state control of the mining sector.
• A study commissioned by the African National Congress (ANC) concluded that nationalising the mines would constitute an "economic disaster," advising against the policy.
• Despite the ANC's official study, supporters within the ANC Youth Employment sector advocate for nationalisation, arguing that it would grant the government direct control over the mining industry.
• Proponents of nationalisation within the ANC Youth Employment movement assert that this policy aligns with the principles outlined in the Freedom Charter, which was signed in 1995.

• The South African government set a target to transfer 30% of the 82 million hectares of land estimated to be owned by white farmers, as stated by Gugile Nkwinti, Minister of Rural Development and Land Reform, equating to 24.5 million hectares, to black farmers by the year 2014.
• By early 2012, a total of 6.7 million hectares had been transferred through land redistribution and restitution programs.
• The land reform program has faced criticism from two primary groups: farmers' organizations and landless workers.
• Landless workers have alleged that the pace of land redistribution has been insufficiently rapid to meet their needs and expectations.

• Farmers' groups have accused the program of anti-white racist treatment, citing threats of genocide that have been openly expressed on multiple occasions by the African National Congress (ANC), including statements from former President Jacob Zuma.
• Concerns have been raised by farmers and other stakeholders about the potential emergence of a situation similar to Zimbabwe's controversial land reform policy.

• These fears were further intensified by comments made by former Deputy President Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, contributing to the apprehension surrounding the direction of South Africa’s land reform initiatives.

• South Africa experiences an extreme and persistent high unemployment rate exceeding 30%, which exacerbates other socioeconomic issues such as inadequate education, poor health, and elevated crime levels.
• The poorest segments of South African society have limited access to economic opportunities and basic services, contributing to widespread poverty.
• A 2013 Goldman Sachs report indicates that the unemployment rate rises to 35% when including individuals who have ceased actively seeking employment.
• Approximately one quarter of South Africans live on less than US$1.25 per day, highlighting severe poverty.
• The phenomenon of mass unemployment in South Africa dates back to the 1970s and continued to escalate through the 1980s and 1990s.
• Since the African National Congress (ANC) assumed power in 1994, unemployment increased significantly from 15.6% in 1995 to 30.3% in 2001.
• In the second quarter of 2010, the unemployment rate rose to 25.3%, with the total number of employed individuals declining by 61,000 to 12,700,000.

• The manufacturing sector experienced the largest employment decline in early 2010, losing 53,000 jobs, followed by agriculture with a loss of 32,000 jobs, and construction with a reduction of 15,000 jobs.
• In the third quarter of 2010, unemployment rates varied by racial group: 29.80% among Blacks, 22.30% among Coloureds, 8.60% among Asians, and 5.10% among Whites.
• The official unemployment rate underestimates the true scale of joblessness because it counts only adults actively seeking work, excluding those who have given up looking.

• Only 41% of South Africa’s working-age population holds any form of employment, whether formal or informal, a figure approximately 30 percentage points lower than China’s employment rate and about 25 percentage points lower than Brazil’s or Indonesia’s.

• South Africa’s relatively generous social grant system mitigates the political consequences of high unemployment; evidence suggests households treat paid employment and social grants as marginal substitutes.
• Households that lose a pension-eligible member tend to report increased labor force participation, indicating a compensatory response to lost social grants.
• The unemployment problem is characterized by its long duration, with nearly two-thirds of unemployed individuals in the mid-1990s having never held salaried employment.
• The 2005 Labour Force Survey revealed that 40% of unemployed persons had been jobless for over three years, and 59% had never had a job at all.
• High unemployment has contributed to increased crime rates, social inequality, and unrest within South African society.
• The global economic downturn exacerbated unemployment by eliminating over one million jobs in South Africa.
• By September 2010, more than one-third of the South African workforce was unemployed, including over half of Black individuals aged 15–34, a rate three times higher than that of Whites.
• Some experts argue that politically powerful trade unions have suppressed job growth by negotiating higher wages.

• A study by economist Dani Rodrik attributes low employment levels more to the contraction of the non-mineral tradable sector since the early 1990s and the weakness of export-oriented manufacturing than to wage pressures.

• Between 1994 and 2004, South Africa experienced significant human capital flight, with the Bureau of Statistics estimating that between 1 million and 1.6 million skilled, professional, and managerial workers emigrated overseas, and for every emigrant, 10 unskilled workers lost their jobs.

• The Southern African Migration Project (SAMP) conducted a study in mid-1998 to assess factors influencing skilled South Africans' desire to emigrate; over two-thirds of respondents had considered emigration, and 38% had given it "a great deal of thought."

• Key reasons cited for emigration included declining quality of life, high crime levels, and opposition to the government's affirmative action policy, which skilled White South Africans felt negatively impacted South Africa and motivated their departure.
• Skilled White South Africans expressed strong opposition to affirmative action policies and the arguments supporting them, viewing these policies as a significant factor driving their emigration.

• The emigration of skilled South Africans is not solely due to domestic factors; active recruitment programs by countries such as the UK, US, Canada, New Zealand, and Australia, which accounted for 75% of recent skilled emigration by volume, have played a major role.
• From 1990 to 1996, the United Kingdom received approximately half of the annual skilled South African emigrants, highlighting its prominence as a destination country.
• Some analyses suggest that domestic socio-political variables may have a negligible role compared to international demand for skilled labor in driving emigration.
• The health sector in South Africa has been particularly affected by the skills drain, with significant losses in medical professionals.

• The financial loss to South Africa from the emigration of doctors is estimated at $1.41 billion in lost returns on investment, while the United Kingdom alone benefits by $2.7 billion from the influx of these medical professionals.

• Between 2008 and 2013, a reverse brain drain occurred with a net return of 359,000 high-skilled South Africans from foreign work assignments, influenced by the 2008 financial crisis and perceptions of a higher quality of life in South Africa compared to the countries they initially emigrated to.
• Approximately 37% of returning professionals during this period were lawyers, doctors, engineers, and accountants, indicating a significant repatriation of skilled labor.
• Refugees from poorer neighbouring countries such as the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, and Malawi constitute a significant portion of South Africa's informal sector.
• High unemployment rates among poorer South Africans contribute to prevalent xenophobia, with many native citizens resenting immigrants whom they perceive as taking jobs away from them.

• This resentment is reinforced by the fact that many South African employers hire migrants from other countries at lower wages than those paid to South African citizens, particularly in sectors such as construction, tourism, agriculture, and domestic service.
• Illegal immigrants are heavily involved in informal trading activities within South Africa.
• Despite their economic participation, many immigrants continue to live in poor conditions within the country.
• Since 1994, South Africa's immigration policy has become increasingly restrictive, reflecting growing concerns over immigration and its socio-economic impacts.

• Since 2007, South African unions representing public sector workers have recurrently engaged in strikes demanding pay rises significantly above inflation, a practice that some experts argue suppresses job growth and negatively impacts millions of unemployed South Africans.
• In August and September 2010, South African unions organised a nationwide strike lasting four weeks, involving 1.3 million public sector workers who demanded an 8.6% wage increase.
• The 2010 strike concluded after the government increased its initial 5.2% wage offer to 7.5%, resulting in an approximate 1% increase in state spending.

• During the 2010 strike, protesters attempted to block hospitals, and South African media reported numerous violent incidents against health and education staff who continued working despite the strike.
• To mitigate the impact of the strike on healthcare services, volunteers and army medics were deployed to assist at hospitals, and some patients were transferred to private medical facilities.

• A persistent wage differential exists in South Africa between unionised and non-unionised workers, indicating that unions maintain higher wages for their members, which contributes additional challenges to addressing the country’s unemployment problem.

• In July 2014, during a national strike involving 220,000 metalworkers, General Motors temporarily shut down its vehicle assembly plant in South Africa, disrupting its plans to produce 50,000 cars annually.
• General Motors stated that ongoing labour disruptions were damaging the South African economy and negatively affecting the country’s international reputation.
• The end of apartheid in 1994 left South Africa with a racially skewed economic hierarchy that positioned minority whites at the top of the economic structure.

• Following apartheid, the African National Congress (ANC) government implemented the Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) policy aimed at increasing economic participation among blacks, Coloreds, and Indians.
• BEE has faced criticism for benefiting only a small elite group rather than broadly empowering the majority of black South Africans.

• In 2010, Deputy President Kgalema Motlanthe acknowledged these shortcomings at the first meeting of the BEE Advisory Council, stating, "The story of black economic empowerment in the last 15 years has been a story dominated by a few individuals benefiting a lot."
• A 2010 OECD report concluded that improvements in poverty levels since apartheid were largely driven by social assistance grants rather than gains in the labor market.
• By 2014, approximately 10% of the Top 100 companies listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange were directly owned by black investors through BEE schemes.
• BEE policies have been credited with creating a class of Black South Africans whose wealth is comparable in magnitude to that of very wealthy White South Africans.
• The stated purpose of Black Economic Empowerment is the "economic empowerment of all black people, including women, workers, youth, people with disabilities and people living in rural areas."
• The Minister of Trade and Industry is mandated to develop and publish Codes of Good Practice, which set guidelines for implementing BEE across the entire economy.

• Compliance with BEE requirements is measured using a scorecard system administered by the Department of Trade and Industry, which influences public procurement, public-private partnerships, sales of state-owned enterprises, license applications, and other economic activities.

• The Development Bank of Southern Africa criticized BEE policies for focusing "almost exclusively on promoting individual ownership by black people," which it argued does little to address broader economic disparities despite increasing diversity among the wealthy.
• The BEE system has been criticized for placing less-educated individuals in important workplace positions, with their underperformance negatively impacting the economy.

• Critics argue that BEE contradicts the constitutional principle of equality by prioritizing racial preference over merit, which some view as contrary to the ideals fought for during the apartheid struggle.
• Official affirmative action policies under BEE have contributed to a rise in black economic wealth and the emergence of a black middle class.
• An increasing number of black candidates, who are intended beneficiaries of affirmative action, are distancing themselves from the policy due to perceptions that appointments are not merit-based.
• The policy has also been criticized for negatively affecting employment levels, being perceived more as an additional burden on employers rather than an effective tool for reducing unemployment.

• This criticism is particularly salient in an economy where a major source of inequality is the growing income disparity within the majority black population, divided along lines of employment status.

• South Africans, irrespective of race, predominantly hold traditional views on gender roles, with men seen as primary breadwinners and women largely not participating in the workforce, reflecting broader traditional African values across the continent.
• The workforce in South Africa is male-dominated, with the majority of women not participating in formal employment sectors.
• Women face significant earnings disparities, with only 77% of women earning the same as their male counterparts, indicating persistent wage inequality.

• As of 2012, there has been a notable increase in women's participation in the agricultural workforce, with women comprising 55% of this sector, signaling a shift towards modernization in women’s economic roles.

• South African legislation strongly promotes gender equality in the workplace through comprehensive government programs and organizations aimed at supporting women, including both adults and adolescents.
• The Employment Equity Act, No. 55 of 1988, is a key legislative measure designed to enhance women’s participation primarily in private sector employment.
• The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) South Africa actively supports and promotes policies and programs aimed at advancing gender equality in the workforce.

• The South African government established the Commission for Gender Equality, which focuses on ensuring adequate education and job training opportunities for women who are disenfranchised or disadvantaged in accessing employment.
• Gender inequality remains a significant issue in the South African workforce, consistent with broader African trends, with many companies lacking female leadership representation.
• According to Bain & Company, approximately 31% of South African companies have no female leadership in either management or executive roles.
• Women constitute 22% of board directors in South African companies, but only 7% hold executive positions, which is below the global average of 12%.

• A survey of 1,000 participants revealed that the Employee Net Promoter Score (eNPS) for women is -4, indicating dissatisfaction, compared to a positive score of 8 for men, reflecting low levels of economic advancement for women despite public and international efforts to promote gender equality.
• Scheduled rolling blackouts have become a routine aspect of daily life in South Africa due to persistent deficiencies in the electrical supply system.
• Electricity theft is widespread across the country, exacerbating the challenges faced by the power infrastructure.

• Since 2007, the state-owned power supplier Eskom has experienced significant capacity deficiencies in both electrical generation and reticulation infrastructure, primarily due to years of sub-standard maintenance and the South African government's inability to effectively manage strategic resources.
• These capacity shortages have resulted in Eskom's inability to meet the routine electricity demands of both industry and consumers, leading to countrywide rolling blackouts.

• The initial trigger for the capacity crisis was a failure at the Koeberg nuclear power station; however, it soon became evident that a general lack of capacity was driven by increased demand and inadequate government planning.
• Both Eskom and the South African government have faced widespread criticism for failing to adequately plan for and construct sufficient electrical generating capacity to meet growing demand.
• Ultimately, the government admitted fault for refusing to approve necessary funding for infrastructure investment, acknowledging its role in the ongoing energy crisis.
• The margin between national electricity demand and available capacity remains low or even negative, especially during peak hours, placing substantial strain on power stations.
• Seasonal surges in demand, particularly during winter, and supply drops often caused by coal shortages at power plants, frequently precipitate new phases of rolling blackouts.
• In response, the government and Eskom are planning the construction of new power stations, with associated costs borne by South African consumers.
• Eskom has set a target to integrate 20,000 megawatts of nuclear power into the national grid by the year 2025 as part of its long-term energy strategy.

• Total energy consumption in South Africa, measured in Terrawatt-hours (TWh), increased from 421 TWh in 1970 to a peak of 1,464 TWh in 2010, before declining to 1,393 TWh in 2020 and further to 1,348 TWh in 2023.

• Per capita energy consumption, measured in Kilowatt-hours (KWh), rose from 18,843 KWh in 1970 to a peak of 28,271 KWh in 2010, followed by a decline to 23,688 KWh in 2020 and 22,314 KWh in 2023, reflecting changes in overall energy use and population growth.
• Predictions indicate that surface water supply in parts of the Western Cape could decrease by 60% by the year 2070, highlighting significant future water scarcity concerns.

• The South African government planned to allocate R69 billion towards water infrastructure development and maintenance between 2008 and 2015, focusing on constructing new dams, ancillary infrastructure, and repairing existing water facilities.

• South Africa’s total estimated water capacity stands at 38 billion cubic metres, which is substantially lower than the projected requirement of 65 billion cubic metres by 2025 to sustain continued economic growth.
• The country’s ageing water infrastructure is under increased pressure due to massive urban migration, resulting in a significant backlog in water service delivery and infrastructure upgrades.
• South Africa is experiencing international pressure to modernize its infrastructure, specifically targeting increased government investment in the water and electricity sectors.
• The water and electricity sectors in South Africa are currently underfunded by approximately US$464 billion, as reported by the G20 Global Infrastructure Hub (G20 GI Hub).

• Annual per capita personal income by race group relative to white levels shows persistent disparities from 1917 to 2008, with whites consistently at 100%, coloureds ranging from 15.6% to 23.0%, Asians increasing from 17.1% to 60.0%, and blacks remaining the lowest from 6.8% to 15.9%.

• In 1917, coloured and Asian incomes were approximately 22% of white incomes, while black incomes were only 9.1% of white levels; by 2008, coloured incomes were 22%, Asians 60%, and blacks 13% relative to whites.

• The Gini coefficient by race in 2004 indicates income inequality within rural, urban, and overall populations: rural Gini coefficients were 0.37 (white), 0.38 (coloured), 0.43 (black), with an overall rural coefficient of 0.51; urban Gini coefficients were higher, with 0.36 (white), 0.45 (coloured), 0.43 (Asian), 0.53 (black), and an overall urban coefficient of 0.56; overall Gini coefficients were 0.36 (white), 0.47 (coloured), 0.43 (Asian), 0.51 (black), and total 0.59.
• South Africa experiences extreme income and wealth disparities, with post-apartheid economic growth leading to a measurable decline in income poverty but an increase in inequality.
• The country’s overall income inequality intensified between 1993 and 2008, as the Gini coefficient rose from 0.66 to 0.70, with income increasingly concentrated in the top decile.
• Urban poverty rates are rising while rural poverty rates are falling, although rural poverty remains substantially higher than urban poverty.

• Between-race inequality is slowly decreasing, but rising intra-race inequality prevents overall inequality measures from declining; real incomes have increased for all groups, yet many black South Africans continue to live in poverty.

• At any poverty line, blacks are significantly poorer than coloureds, who are poorer than Asians, who in turn are poorer than whites; in 2002, poverty rates were estimated at 62% for Black Africans, 29% for Coloureds, 11% for Asians, and 4% for Whites.

• Mean per capita income rose from R10,741 in 1993 to R24,409 in 2008, but large disparities remain within and across population groups: average Black income increased from R6,018 to R9,718; Coloured income rose from R7,498 to R25,269; White income increased from R29,372 to R110,195.

• From 1993 to 2008, mean income increased by approximately 130%, while median income rose only 15%, from R4,444 to R5,096, indicating income growth driven by a small number of very high earners, especially among Whites.
• In 2000, the average white household earned six times more than the average black household.
• In 2004, 29.8% of all South African households had an annual income below R9,600 (at constant 2001 prices), while 10.3% had an annual income exceeding R153,601 (at constant 2001 prices).

• A study using National Income Dynamics Study (NIDS) data estimated that 47% of South Africans lived below the poverty line, with 56% of blacks and 2% of whites below this threshold, using an arbitrary income poverty line of R502 per capita.
• According to the 2011 Statistics South Africa census, black South Africans constitute 79.2% of the population, while white South Africans comprise 8.9%.

• The United Nations Development Program’s Human Development Index (HDI) ranked South Africa 110th out of 169 countries in 2010, noting slow improvement since 1980; the Human Poverty Index (HPI-1) ranked South Africa 85th out of 135 countries.
• A study assessing poverty by apartheid-era social categories found 56% of blacks, 27% of coloureds, 9% of Indians, and 2% of whites living below the poverty line.

• Historically, South African inequality was largely defined along racial lines, but it is increasingly characterized by inequality within racial groups due to widening gaps between rich and poor within each group.

• The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) proposed measures to address income inequality in South Africa, including encouraging saving and investment, liberalizing product-market regulation, improving access to credit for small businesses, enhancing wage bargaining coordination, and tackling high youth unemployment.
• OECD proposals also suggested wage subsidies for trainees, age-differentiated minimum wages, and extended probation periods for young workers.
• Post-apartheid income gap closure has been most significant among Asians relative to Whites, while Coloured and Black South Africans have experienced more limited progress.
• A 2011 University of Cape Town study on the richest 10% of South Africans found that nearly 40% are black, a significant change from the past when this group was almost exclusively white.
• Among the "entry-level" rich (earning more than $4,000 per month), 50% are black, with common characteristics including youth, entrepreneurship, and some post-secondary education.
• In 2004, an estimated 10.4% of South Africans belonged to the "higher middle class," defined as having a per capita income exceeding R40,000 (in 2000 Rand).
• The highest personal income tax rate in South Africa is set at 45%.
• The corporate tax rate applicable to companies in South Africa is 27%.
• South Africa imposes additional taxes including a value-added tax (VAT) and a capital gains tax.
• The total tax burden in South Africa constitutes 23.4% of the country's total domestic income.

• South Africa has an exceptionally high ratio of social benefit recipients to income taxpayers, with about three times as many recipients as taxpayers, a figure that is notably high by international standards.

• Since 1994, there has been a rapid reallocation of social spending resources towards black households; in the mid-1980s, approximately 40% of aggregate social spending was directed to white households and 43% to black households.

• By the late 1990s, the distribution of total social spending shifted significantly, with about 80% allocated to black households and less than 10% to white households, reflecting a major policy and demographic change post-apartheid.

• Currently, black South Africans contribute approximately 50% of total government transfers but receive around 80% of these transfers, indicating a redistribution of social benefits in favor of black populations.
• The Unemployment Insurance Fund (UIF) in South Africa is financed through premiums and contributions paid by workers and employers, with the benefits provided being earnings-related.
• The UIF is designed to insure workers against the risk of income loss due to unemployment, serving as a social safety net mechanism within the South African economy.

• Social assistance grants in South Africa are non-contributory, income-tested benefits provided by the state to impoverished individuals, funded through general tax revenues without any direct link between contributions and benefits.

• These grants are categorized into several types: grants for older persons, disability grants, war veterans grants, care dependency grants, foster child grants, child support grants, grant-in-aid, and social relief of distress.

• The state old age pension, which is non-contributory, is received by over 80% of the elderly population and pays more than twice the median per capita Black income, making it a significant source of income for approximately one-third of all Black households in South Africa.
• As of July 2019, the state old age pension pays a maximum amount of R1,780 per month to individuals who reach pension age without access to private pension schemes.

• The child support grant provides R420 per month, per child (as of July 2019), for every child in a household under the age of 18, and by April 2009, this grant benefited 9.1 million children across the country.
• The war veterans grant is allocated to former soldiers who participated in the Second World War or the Korean War, with a maximum monthly payment of R1,800 as of July 2019.

• According to a December 2010 article by the South African Government Communication and Information System's now-defunct BuaNews news service, South Africa compared well to other emerging markets in terms of affordability and availability of capital, financial market sophistication, business tax rates, and infrastructure.

• The same article noted that South Africa performed poorly relative to other emerging markets regarding the cost and availability of labour, education quality, and the use of technology and innovation.
• South Africa possesses expertise in the Space industry, with students gaining knowledge through the South African Students for the Exploration and Development of Space (SEDS) program.
• With appropriate government support, South Africa has the potential to increase employment opportunities in manufacturing, testing, and analysis sectors within the growing Space industry.

• A survey titled "Competitividade Brasil 2010: Comparaçao com Paises Selecionados" (Competition Brazil: A comparison with selected countries), released in early December 2010 by Brazil's National Confederation of Industry and no longer available online, ranked South Africa as having the second most sophisticated financial market among 14 surveyed countries.
• The same survey found South Africa to have the second-lowest effective business tax rate, measured as business taxes as a percentage of company profits, out of the 14 countries surveyed.
• South Africa was ranked fourth for ease of accessing capital and fourth for the cost of capital in the 2010 survey.
• The country was ranked sixth for transport infrastructure, which at the time was considered superior to that of China, India, Mexico, Brazil, and Poland, but behind South Korea and Chile.
• South Africa was ranked seventh for foreign direct investment as a percentage of GDP, with foreign direct investment exceeding 3% of GDP in 2008.

• Despite these strengths, South Africa is falling behind other emerging markets such as India and China due to several factors: its relatively small size without a large domestic consumer base; a decades-long unusually low rate of saving and investment partly caused by low disposable income levels.

• Additional challenges include an inadequate education system resulting in an acute shortage of skilled manpower, a strong and volatile currency that deters investors and reduces export competitiveness, and infrastructure bottlenecks including scheduled power shortages that urgently require upgrading.

• In 2011, after a year of observer status, South Africa officially joined the BRICS group of emerging-market nations at the summit held in Sanya, Hainan, China, expanding the group to five countries.
